Award.AwardTitle: CAS: Harnessing the disordered state in block polymer materials for high-efficiency separations
Award.AbstractNarration:
PART 1: NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY

Ready access to clean water is a pressing global challenge that represents one of the most important sustainability issues we face as a society. Desalination of sea water and wastewater remediation/reuse are two prevalent solutions that will benefit from new advances in basic materials research. These approaches to generating clean water for consumption rely on the use of membranes endowed with material properties designed to optimize separations performance. This research project focuses on new state-of-the-art polymeric materials designed to address key limitations that must be overcome to further advance understanding and efficacy of materials used in membrane-based separations. The objectives are to design and advance the use of block polymer materials for membranes using a combination of contemporary polymer synthesis, thorough materials characterization, and integration of new macromolecules into practical separation membranes. The research promises to benefit society through the eventual development of new technologies that render water purification and remediation more economical and more widely accessible. Membranes will play important roles in a sustainable water future and the fundamental underpinnings achieved in this work will help solidify the foundations from which new technologies will be built. The work will also build diverse STEM talent though partnerships that include the NorthStar STEM Alliance, American Chemical Societyâ€™s Project SEED, and the University of Minnesota's Science for All group.


PART 2: TECHNICAL SUMMARY

The research work centers around the design, development, and deployment of block polymer centric strategies that rely on the self-assembly of novel compounds to take advantage of their nanostructured morphologies. Co-continuous nanostructures are essential to advance the design of materials for next-generation water purification membranes, and this research will advance knowledge useful for the creation of co-continuous nanostructured polymer materials that are useful for aqueous-based separations. The essential feature of the program emphasizes the preparation of materials with co-continuous nanostructures by capitalizing on the disordered state of block polymer derived materials. The work will advance knowledge in two main categories. The first is based on a thermodynamic approach that entails trapping a disordered co-continuous morphology in the thermodynamically stable disordered state using pre-formed block polymers. The second is based on a kinetic approach that entails trapping the disordered state during the in-situ synthesis of block polymers in a system that is conducive to chemical fixation through crosslinking. The fundamental and basic research efforts will advance knowledge in these two arenas, will contribute to the basic understanding of block polymer thermodynamics, and will ultimately allow for new technologies to be built that contribute to sustainable access to clean water.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The design, development, and deployment of new polymeric materials useful for various types of separations is a critical research endeavor. This National Science Foundation grant supported our work focused on using a particular class of specialty polymers called block polymers. These macromolecules contain two or more distinct components that endow them with remarkable chemical and physical properties and that result in materials with a tunable array of attractive characteristics. The bulk of our work under this award focused on the careful design of block polymers such that they adopted a particular structure on the nanoscale. Specifically, we designed systems that formed interwoven domains of polymeric species that permeated the entire material. These so-called bicontinuous structures are incredibly useful in, for example, membranes that are both mechanically robust and can also facilitate transport of liquids such as water. In several examples, we showed that if one of the domains can be selectively removed from the bicontinuous structures, nanoscopic pores that percolate the entire material can be generated. These materials can be used in numerous applications that include the selective removal of impurities (e.g., viruses and other pathogens) from water with membrane technologies (e.g., in wastewater remediation). These approaches to generating clean water for consumption rely on the use of membranes endowed with material properties designed to optimize separations performance.

In addition to our work on porous materials, we also made several advances in nanostructure materials containing ionically charged domains. In this work, we discovered a new method for the generation of materials that simultaneously contained oppositely charged anionic and cationic domains in a single functionalization step. The work is critically important for the formation of a unique class of materials useful in water desalination called charge mosaic membranes that can selectively remove dissolved salts from water. We did this by designing and preparing functional block polymer that could readily self-assembly into interesting and useful nanostructures. 

During this award we also recognized the need to develop even more robust polymeric materials using the modern tools of chemistry. To this end, we showed that we could use a single catalyst not only for the polymerization chemistry, but also for the chemical modification of the product polymers that rendered them much more chemically resistant while also allow for the integration of chemical handles for further functionalization. This major advance has led to new research endeavors and new lines of investigation that will be important for the development of unique materials with many practical outlets. 

We have made numerous fundamental materials research contributions under this grant that have been published in the top peer-reviewed journals.

The direct basic research science outcomes from this award were complemented by broader impacts of the award that went beyond the scientific findings. For example, some of our research efforts led to materials useful for the compatibilization of mixed plastic waste in recycling enabling more strategic and sustainable methods for handling plastic waste at the end of life. We were also successful in building Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) talent through researcher training under this award. Several researchers supported were also from underrepresented groups in the sciences thus helping diversity the STEM workforce. We also made several contributions to scientific outreach and polymer science education. 

In sum, we have advanced the use of block polymer materials for use in membranes using a combination of contemporary polymer synthesis, careful and thorough materials characterization and developed new materials for practical separation membranes. This award enabled not only important scientific discoveries but also had broader implications for society, the STEM workforce, and polymer science training and education.
